article.title: SPIDERS: Selection of spectroscopic targets using AGN candidates detected in all-sky X-ray surveys

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main reason for the non-uniform distribution of RASS X-ray sources across the sky?
choices: The varying Galactic column density obscures X-ray sources differently across the sky.
Variations in the effective exposure time and background count rate during the ROSAT survey.
The XMMSL survey has a higher detection sensitivity than the RASS survey.
The clustering of X-ray sources in galaxy clusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which statement best describes the relationship between the X-ray flux distributions of the RASS and XMMSL samples?
choices: The RASS and XMMSL samples have identical flux distributions.
XMMSL sources are typically brighter in the soft X-ray band (0.1-2.4 keV) than RASS sources.
XMMSL sources are typically brighter in the hard X-ray band (0.2-12 keV) than RASS sources.
The 3XMM-Bright sample covers a narrower range of fluxes than both the RASS and XMMSL samples.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does the prior Π([W2],[W1 −W2]) provide in the context of the Bayesian cross-matching process?
choices: The probability of an AllWISE source being a spurious detection.
The relative likelihood of an AllWISE source at a given location in color-magnitude space being a true counterpart to an X-ray source.
The angular separation between an X-ray source and its potential AllWISE counterpart.
The positional uncertainty of an AllWISE source.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the flow chart, what is the final step in selecting SPIDERS_RASS_AGN targets?
choices: Removing previously spectroscopically identified sources using SDSS-proto-DR12 data.
Removing sources that lie within the BOSS-DR10 bright star mask.
Matching the best AllWISE counterpart to an SDSS-DR13 optical counterpart.
Calculating the Bayesian posterior probability of association between RASS and AllWISE sources.
